Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Numerical Modeling of Low-Rise Reinforced Concrete Shear Walls with High-Strength Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent earthquakes (e.g., Northridge 1994, Chile 2010) are reminders that there is still much research to be done on the seismic design of building structures. In many low-rise reinforced concrete (RC) structures, common in residential and nuclear-safety related applications), the primary lateral load resisting systems against earthquakes are shear walls. It would be possible to increase the efficiency of low-rise shear walls by using high-strength steel reinforcement and high-strength concrete. However, due to lack of research and testing, high-strength reinforcement in most applications is not yet accepted by the American Concrete Institute building codes. The aim of this research is to better understand the behavior of low-rise RC shear walls with high-strength materials. The project will be conducted at the Earthquake Research Institute, University of Tokyo, with host researcher, Prof. Toshimi Kabeyasawa. The results of the research have the potential to not only cut construction costs but also improve the resistance and reliability of these structures under seismic hazards.

Due to their low height-to-length aspect ratio (smaller than 2:1), the failure of low-rise RC walls is dominated by shear, which is non-ductile and strength governed. This failure mechanism matches the material properties of high-strength reinforcement and high-strength concrete, which provide higher resistance utilizing less material. The principal investigator will perform pre- and post-test detailed numerical analyses of experimental wall specimens, which are being tested at the University of Notre Dame as part of a project funded by the U.S. Department of Energy. Numerical modeling techniques from the U.S. as well as those developed in Japan will be implemented and compared. The results of the study will be integral for the design of subsequent experimental wall test specimen parameters, such as reinforcement grade, reinforcement ratio, concrete compressive strength, and moment-to-shear ratio.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent earthquakes are reminders that research into the seismic behavior of building structures is critical to public safety. In many buildings, the primary earthquake load resisting systems are reinforced concrete (RC) shear walls. The use of high-strength reinforcing bars (rebar) and high-strength concrete (as compared with the current industry-standard materials) can have significant economic benefits by reducing the construction and material costs of RC shear walls; however, an important limitation has been the reduced deformation capacity of high-strength materials, which can reduce the lateral displacement capacity of RC structures. As a result, the use of high-strength materials in seismic regions is currently not allowed by the governing U.S. building design codes. My PhD research specifically focuses on low-rise (height to length ratio < 2) RC shear walls with high-strength rebar and concrete, with the goal of providing the necessary research basis for the acceptance of these materials in U.S. seismic building and nuclear structure design codes. Low-rise RC walls are especially suitable for high-strength rebar and concrete because the design of these structures is governed by lateral forces, rather than displacements, with significantly reduced demands for material deformations. This work is part of a U.S. Department of Energy Nuclear Energy University Program project at the University of Notre Dame.

As part of the NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes (EAPSI) for U.S. Graduate Students, I performed research at the Earthquake Research Institute (ERI), University of Tokyo under the supervision of Prof. Toshimi Kabeyasawa, a world renowned expert in the behavior of reinforced concrete walls under seismic loading conditions. My research during this fellowship focused on numerically predicting the peak lateral strength of forty RC walls using a nonlinear finite element analysis software package. This parametric numerical investigation included varying the: 1) concrete compression strength; 2) rebar yield strength; 3) reinforcement ratio; and 4) base moment-to-shear ratio. My work informed the design of specimens for two types of experimental testing at the University of Notre Dame: 1) partial shear wall slices tested monotonically as deep beams to determine the effect of high-strength materials on the monotonic lateral strength and stiffness, and 2) shear wall specimens tested under reversed-cyclic lateral loads typical of earthquakes. My numerical models also served to develop pre-test predictions for these experiments. Ultimately, the laboratory measurements will be compared with my numerical predictions, culminating in refined and validated models. Further research with these validated models will include parametric investigations to extend the research conclusions beyond what could be tested experimentally.

While at ERI, I also gained valuable knowledge from Japanese researchers with experience in testing RC structural members with high-strength materials and innovative seismic retrofit solutions for RC walls. I assisted Prof. Kabeyasawa and his students with the experimental testing of four shear walls utilizing super reinforcement with flexibility (a durable exterior fabric sheet wrap for RC structures) as a retrofit option. My responsibilities included physical assistance of the experiments and continued collaboration in analyzing the tests.

In addition to my work at ERI, I visited other research institutes, including E-Defense (home to the largest earthquake simulator in the world), Osaka University, and Tohoku University, to learn from Japanese researchers. After discussions with professors and students, I learned about modeling and experimental techniques utilized at these facilities. Current high-priority research in Japan includes reducing damage to non-structural building walls, developing appropriate reinforcement detailing of seismic resisting structures in developing nations, and investigating residual structural capacity after major seismic events.

My fellowship in Japan was invaluable to both my development as a researcher and a person of an increasingly global world. The techniques I learned and the relationships I formed during my EAPSI experience will shape my research going forward and provide opportunities for future collaborations.
